results.title: Albany whaling
results.brief_description: Recounts the history of whaling on Australia’s West Coast with rare footage from early twentieth century to the last whale to be taken by the Cheynes Beach company. Includes scenes of harpooning with the grenade-head gun and the confrontation of Dr Jim Cairns’ Greenpeace Group and Albany citizens who felt that closure would endanger their homes and livings.

results.title: Alaska: reservoir of resources
results.creator_credit: EB Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: This film depicts the timber industry in Aalska in its early stages. Also shows salmon fishing during the short Summer season when 100s of millions of pounds of fish are netted under government supervision. Within the two months of the fishing and canning season many millions of dollars are made from this production. Gold mining is also carried out using cannon jets of water. During the short Summer season a variety of products are produced on the farms.

results.title: Alaska: a modern frontier
results.brief_description: Alaska is not all snow, but a modern country with modern cities, housing and farming with a highway now linking it to the United States. This film shows of the progress made and comments on the progress still to come.

results.title: Alan Wake
results.brief_description: The story follows best-selling thriller novelist Alan Wake, as he tries to uncover the mystery behind his wife’s disappearance during a vacation in the small fictional town of Bright Falls, Washington, all while experiencing events from the plot in his latest novel, which he cannot remember writing, coming to life.

results.title: Akermania: shorter works by Chantal Akerman [NTSC]
results.brief_description: Chantal Akerman, one of contemporary cinema’s singular filmmakers, is the director of these three engaging short films about women finding their way in the world. “I’m hungry, I’m cold”: Two young Belgian girls run away from home in Brussels. They spend a day and an evening looking for food and love, with comic and poignant results. Stars Maria de Medeiros. “Blow up my town”: A young woman (Akerman) comes home to her apartment in Brussels where she cooks pasta and seals herself in with duct tape. An amusing and wonderfully observational piece, evocative of early Buster Keaton work with its virtually dialogue-less track, Akerman’s first film was made at the age of 18. “Hotel Monterey”: A stark and silent look at a New York pension hotel, Akerman roams the corridors, stairwells, lifts and crammed apartments of the dwelling, looking for signs of life, human interaction and connections between the inhabitants. This experimental piece, reminiscent of the 1970s work of Andy Warhol, is considered in many ways a non-narrative study for “Jeanne Dielman” Akerman’s iconic 1975 feminist, experimental feature.

results.title: Airborne
results.creator_credit: Chris Dillon, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Explores the rugged inaccessible country where deer can be found. It contains thrilling sequences of low level flight over spectacularly beautiful unexplored terrain, and culminates in the excitement of a live deer capture.

results.title: Air pollution: a first film
results.creator_credit: Norman Bean and Norman Bean Films
results.brief_description: This film explains that almost all of man’s activities can contribute to air pollution. It outlines the problems associated with air pollution and indicates that everyone must share in correcting pollution problems. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
